title: THE EARLY DIVERSIFICATION HISTORY OF DIDELPHID MARSUPIALS: A WINDOW INTO SOUTH AMERICA'S "SPLENDID ISOLATION"
abstract: The geological record of South American mammals is spatially biased because productive fossil sites are concentrated at high latitudes. As a result, the history of mammalian diversification in Amazonia and other tropical biomes is largely unknown. Here we report diversification analyses based on a time-calibrated molecular phylogeny of opossums (Didelphidae), a species-rich clade of mostly tropical marsupials descended from a Late Oligocene common ancestor. Optimizations of habitat and geography on this phylogeny suggest that (1) basal didelphid lineages inhabited South American moist forests; (2) didelphids did not diversify in dry-forest habitats until the Late Miocene; and (3) most didelphid lineages did not enter North America until the Pliocene. We also summarize evidence for an Early-to Middle-Miocene mass extinction event, for which alternative causal explanations are discussed. To the best of our knowledge, this study provides the first published molecular-phylogenetic evidence for mass extinction in any animal clade, and it is the first time that evidence for such an event (in any plant or animal taxon) has been tested for statistical significance. Potentially falsifying observations that could help discriminate between the proposed alternative explanations for didelphid mass extinction may be obtainable from diversification analyses of other sympatric mammalian groups.

abstract.text: The geological record of South American mammals is spatially biased because productive fossil sites are concentrated at high latitudes. As a result, the history of mammalian diversification in Amazonia and other tropical biomes is largely unknown. Here we report diversification analyses based on a time-calibrated molecular phylogeny of opossums (Didelphidae), a species-rich clade of mostly tropical marsupials descended from a Late Oligocene common ancestor. We also summarize evidence for an Early-to Middle-Miocene mass extinction event, for which alternative causal explanations are discussed. To the best of our knowledge, this study provides the first published molecular-phylogenetic evidence for mass extinction in any animal clade, and it is the first time that evidence for such an event (in any plant or animal taxon) has been tested for statistical significance. Potentially falsifying observations that could help discriminate between the proposed alternative explanations for didelphid mass extinction may be obtainable from diversification analyses of other sympatric mammalian groups.

body_text.text: Throughout most of the Tertiary, South America was an island continent separated from North America and Antarctica by open seaways. During this long period of "Splendid Isolation" (Simpson 1980) , an extraordinary mammalian fauna evolved from a small number of Paleocene taxa (Simpson's Stratum 1: marsupials, xenarthrans, and archaic "ungulates") together with a few overwater immigrants that arrived in the late Eocene or early Oligocene (Stratum 2: primates and caviomorph rodents). The radiations that descended from these founding stocks alternately flourished or dwindled in diversity for tens of millions of years, resulting in a continental fauna of strikingly high endemicity. Then, beginning in the late Miocene and markedly accelerating in the Pliocene, a host of North American mammals (Stratum 3: artiodactyls, carnivorans, squirrels, cricetid rodents, etc.) entered the continent over the emerging Panamanian land bridge, resulting in faunal enrichment, extinction of some native clades, and explosive radiations of immigrant lineages.

As reconstructed by several generations of paleontologists (Scott 1913; Matthew 1915; Simpson 1940 Simpson , 1950 Simpson , 1969 Patterson and Pascual 1972; Marshall et al. 1982; Stehli and Webb 1985; Marshall and Sempere 1993; Flynn and Wyss 1998; MacFadden 2006) , this scenario is based on an impressively detailed body of geological evidence. Nevertheless, the South American fossil record has significant shortcomings, the most important of which is a strong geographic bias. With a few noteworthy exceptions (e.g., Kay et al. 1997; Campbell 2004) , productive fossil localities are concentrated at high latitudes, mostly in Argentina (Patterson and Pascual 1972; Marshall and Sempere 1993) . As a result, the South American fossil record is largely uninformative about the tempo and mode of mammalian evolution in Amazonia and other tropical biomes that now support highly diverse faunas (Voss and Emmons 1996) .

Molecular phylogenies of extant taxa can provide information about aspects of biotic evolution that are not preserved in the geological record, and they can also be used to test the predictions of paleontological scenarios. Episodes of rapid radiation and mass extinction, for example, can be detected from analyses of net diversification (Nee et al. 1992; Nee et al. 1994a, b ; Barraclough and Nee 2001; Nee 2001; Rabosky 2006; Purvis 2008; Crisp and Cook 2009) , and ancestral trait reconstructions on time-calibrated trees can be used to test causal hypotheses about historical patterns of faunal evolution (Weir 2006; Barker 2007; Wiens et al. 2007; Skinner et al. 2008) . To date, however, few molecular phylogenies of Neotropical mammals have been used for such purposes. Although many clades are attractive research candidates, only one group is potentially informative about macroevolutionary and biogeographic phenomena throughout the Age of Mammals in South America.

The New World marsupial family Didelphidae, commonly known as opossums, is the only diverse lineage of Recent mammals descended from Simpson's Stratum 1, the original early Tertiary fauna of South America (other Stratum 1 survivors, such as xenarthrans, are more-or-less relictual groups in modern faunas). Approximately 100 didelphid species in 19 genera are currently recognized, of which almost 90% of the species and 50% of the genera are South American endemics; only three species and one genus are endemic to North America (Voss and Jansa 2009) . Although a few opossums occupy temperate latitudes, high elevations, or xeric habitats, most species are found in lowland tropical rainforests, where they occupy a diversity of ecological niches ranging from aquatic carnivory to arboreal frugivory (Charles-Dominique 1983; Julien-Laferriere and Atramentowicz 1990; Fleck and Harder 1995; Voss and Emmons 1996) . The recent completion of phylogenetic studies of didelphids based on nuclear genes and morphology (Jansa and Voss 2000; Voss and Jansa 2003; Voss et al. 2004; Jansa and Voss 2005; Voss and Jansa 2009 ) now provides a basis for inference about the tempo and mode of evolution in the early radiation of this group of quintessentially Neotropical mammals.

Our taxon sample includes representative species of every currently recognized didelphid genus except Chacodelphys (for which no tissue samples are currently available). Additionally, it includes at least one representative of most traditionally recognized subgenera (only the subgenus Xerodelphys of Thylamys is not represented), and it includes exemplars of all traditionally recognized species groups in genera lacking formal subdivisions. Published and unpublished phylogenetic analyses of mitochondrial gene sequences (e.g., by Mustrangi and Patton 1997; Patton and da Silva 1997; Giarla et al. 2010; Gutiérrez et al. 2010; J. F. Díaz-Nieto and S. Pavan, pers. comm.) and morphology (Voss and Jansa 2009) suggest that the species we sampled for nuclear genes include descendants of the basal split within each genus (except Thylamys), and that all omitted taxa represent late Tertiary (mostly Pliocene) or Quaternary cladogenic events.

cite_spans.text: J. F. Díaz-Nieto and S. Pavan, pers. comm.)

body_text.section: TAXON SAMPLING, PHYLOGENETIC ANALYSIS, AND DIVERGENCE-TIME ESTIMATION

body_text.text: Our estimates of opossum phylogeny and divergence times are based on analyses of 5460 bp of DNA sequence from four independent nuclear loci: BRCA1 (2163 bp), DMP1 (1176 bp), IRBP (1158 bp), and vWF (963 bp) (see Voss and Jansa 2009 for details) . In addition to 43 species of didelphids, our taxon sample included seven non-didelphid marsupials representing the orders Paucituberculata (Caenolestes fuliginosus and Rhyncholestes raphanurus), Microbiotheria (Dromiciops gliroides), Peramelemorphia (Perameles gunnii and Echymipera kalubu), and Dasyuromorphia (Sminthopsis crassicaudata and Murexia longicaudata) as well as five placental outgroups representing the lineages Afrotheria (Orycteropus afer), Laurasiatheria (Equus caballus), Euarchontoglires (Erethizon dorsatum, Oryctolagus cuniculus), and Xenarthra (Bradypus tridactylus or Dasypus novemcinctus). We used heuristic searches under the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), as implemented in PartitionFinder (Lanfear et al. 2012) , to determine the optimal among-gene partitioning scheme and model choice for our dataset. We inferred a time-scaled phylogeny for these taxa by implementing these substitution models in a Bayesian relaxed-clock analysis using BEAST (version 1.7.2; Drummond and Rambaut 2007) with nodes constrained by the fossil record (see Fig. S1 ; BEAST files archived at Dryad doi:10.5061/dryad.f1r72). We assumed an exponential prior for the uncorrelated lognormal relaxed-clock rate, with mean = 0.1 and standard deviation = 0.33. This prior encompasses the commonly cited estimate of 10 −9 substitutions/site/million years for mammalian nuclear gene evolution (e.g., Kumar and Subramanian 2002) . Given our incomplete species sampling, we assumed a Yule process with a diffuse exponential prior on the diversification rate with a mean of 1.0. As calibration points for this analysis, we set a uniform prior on the age of the basal divergence within Marsupialia with minimum and maximum bounds of 54.6 and 83.5 million years (Ma), respectively, and a uniform prior on the age of Theria (Marsupialia + Placentalia) with bounds of 125 and 200 Ma. We used three minimum divergence dates within the marsupial radiation, and assumed a log-normal distribution with the following means and standard deviation of 1.0 for each: (1) the divergence between Didelphis and Philander at 3.3 Ma; (2) the split between Monodelphis and Marmosa at 12.1 Ma; and (3) the split between the Old World marsupial orders Dasyuromorphia and Peramelemorphia at 24.7 Ma. After discarding the initial 10,000 generations as burn-in, we ran the Markov chain for 10 7 generations, recording parameters every 1000 generations. To test whether patterns of branching times were consistent across all four genes, we repeated this analysis for each gene independently, using the same priors, run settings, and calibration points. In addition, to test for possible calibration effects, we analyzed the four-gene dataset in relative time rather than absolute time (with the prior for the root time set to one, and no calibration points included).
body_text.section: TAXON SAMPLING, PHYLOGENETIC ANALYSIS, AND DIVERGENCE-TIME ESTIMATION

body_text.text: To infer the ecological context of didelphid evolution, we coded each terminal taxon as occurring in either moist (evergreen) forest or dry forest (including tree savannas, thornscrub, and other open vegetation formations), and reconstructed ancestral habitats on the time-scaled phylogeny using likelihood reconstructions under an equal-rates (Mk) model (as implemented in Mesquite version 2.73; Maddison and Maddison 2011) . In addition, we used a Dispersal-Extinction-Cladogenesis (DEC) model (Ree and Smith 2008) to infer the biogeographic history of didelphids. To implement the DEC analysis, we coded terminal taxa as occurring in South America, North America (including Central America), or both; we used the time-scaled phylogeny resulting from the BEAST analysis described earlier; and we used the unconstrained option for biogeographic range evolution in LaGrange (Ree and Smith 2008) .
body_text.section: TAXON SAMPLING, PHYLOGENETIC ANALYSIS, AND DIVERGENCE-TIME ESTIMATION

body_text.text: We constructed a lineage-through-time (LTT) plot based on the time-scaled maximum-clade-credibility tree derived from the BEAST analysis and evaluated the fit of a birth-death model to these branching times using methods implemented in the R package geiger (Harmon et al. 2008 ). Because we lack complete species-level sampling, fitting a generalized birth-death model to the branching time data alone is inappropriate, as we fail to sample the "pull of the recent" that distinguishes the birth rate (λ) from the net diversification rate (defined as λ-μ, where μ is the extinction rate) that controls the slope of the LTT relationship over most of a clade's history (Nee et al. 1994b ). Rabosky and colleagues (Rabosky et al. 2007; Alfaro et al. 2009) overcame this limitation by evaluating a hybrid likelihood that integrates both branching-time estimates and the known diver-sity of incompletely sampled clades, which is the basis for the MEDUSA algorithm. Using code modified from the internal geiger function getDiversificationModel() (and archived at Dryad doi:10.5061/dryad.f1r72), we applied this model to the opossum data by pruning the didelphid phylogeny down to tips representing clades whose extant diversity could be circumscribed (Table S2) . We then estimated the maximum likelihood point of the uniformrate birth-death process using runMedusa(), and approximated confidence intervals on these values by mapping the −1, −2, and −3 log-likelihood contours on a likelihood surface calculated for a wide range of net diversification rates and extinction fractions.

The best data-partitioning scheme for this dataset, as determined by the BIC, contained three partitions: BRCA1, IRBP + vWF, and DMP1, with best-fitting nucleotide substitution models of TrN+ , GTR+I+ , and GTR+ , respectively. The tree resulting from our BEAST analysis of the four-gene dataset under these models ( Fig. 1 ) agrees well with our previously published analysis of a combined dataset that included both molecular and morphological characters ( fig. 35 in Voss and Jansa 2009) . Divergence-time estimates derived from this analysis suggest that the basal split within the didelphid clown clade occurred in the Late Oligocene (26.3 Ma; 95% credible interval = 20.0-33.2 Ma; Table S1 ). Based on maximum-likelihood reconstruction of habitats on this phylogeny, the early diversification of opossums (before about 17 Ma) occurred entirely within moist-forest biomes, with most subsequent invasions of dry-forest biomes occurring during or after the late Miocene (∼10 Ma). An unconstrained DEC model of range evolution unequivocally reconstructs a South American origin of didelphids (relative probability of the basal split occurring within South America = 0.998), with most subsequent pre-Pliocene cladogenic events receiving high relative probability (> 0.95) of having occurred within that continent.
body_text.section: PHYLOGENY, BASAL DIVERGENCE TIME, AND ECOGEOGRAPHIC ORIGIN

body_text.text: Based on calculations using hybrid branching-time/species-count likelihoods (Rabosky et al. 2007; Alfaro et al. 2009) , our data strongly reject a pure-birth model for opossum diversification (equivalent to a = μ/λ = 0 in Fig. 2 ). In fact, point estimates of diversification parameters suggest that didelphids experienced a relatively low net diversification rate (r = λ − μ = 0.11 species/Ma) and high extinction fraction (a = 0.77) over the Tertiary interval represented by these data. However, a uniform (constant-rate) model does not appear to adequately describe the temporal pattern of didelphid diversification recovered by our analyses. The red line demarcates the combinations of parameter values yielding 5% probability of a ninth diversification interval as long as or longer than that observed (Fig. 3) .

A striking feature of our log-lineages-through-time plot (Fig. 3A) is a long interval of zero net diversification between 15.0 and 9.4 Ma. This interval-the ninth between successive speciation events (counting from the origin of Didelphidae)-is significantly longer than all but the first five intervals (Fig. 3B ) and is flanked by two episodes of approximately linear lineage accumulation, one from 26.2 to 15.0 Ma and the other from 9.4 Ma to the point at which we truncated the lineageaccumulation plot due to incomplete species-level sampling. This anomalously long interval is hard to reconcile with the expected results of any uniform-rate diversification process and resembles diversification plateaus resulting from mass extinction in simulated phylogenies Crisp and Cook 2009) . To assess the macroevolutionary significance of this interval, we tested the hypothesis that an interval as long or longer than the ninth in our tree could have arisen from a generalized birth-death process across a wide range of net diversification rates and extinction fractions.

Intervals between successive speciation events in phylogenetic trees reconstructed from Recent taxa are expected to be longer toward the base of the tree than at later stages of clade diversification because there are fewer speciating lineages at earlier stages, and because the probability that any particular lineage will go extinct increases over time ). Therefore, it is necessary to test whether the ninth interval in our results is longer than would be expected given its position in the tree. No appropriate standard test for such a deviation has been proposed, so we designed the following approach. First, we estimated the likelihood surface for the divergence-time data from the ratesmoothed tree over the net diversification rate (r = λ − μ) and extinction fraction (a = μ/λ) parameters using the composite likelihood function of Rabosky et al. (2007) and Alfaro et al. (2009) , which allowed us to place approximate confidence intervals on these parameters given our data (Fig. 2) . On the same axes, we then estimated the 5% probability contour for recovering a ninth interval greater than or equal to 5.6 million years using the tail probability for that interval's waiting time (eq. 15 in Nee et al. 1994b) ; this probability is conditioned on the number of lineages at that point in the clade's history, the start date of the interval, and the input values of r and a. Clearly, only values of r and a that are highly unlikely given our data (i.e., 3 log-likelihood units from the maximum likelihood point for these data) yield reasonable (>5%) probabilities of observing such a long ninth interval, and on this basis we reject a uniform birth-death process as an adequate description of our data.

This long interval appears to be a real feature of didelphid diversification history and is not attributable to any of several potential artifacts. First, this interval appears to be a consistent feature regardless of uncertainty in the tree topology. To assess the impact of topological uncertainty on interval length, we calculated the 95% credible interval of interval lengths based on the 10,000 post-burnin trees derived from the BEAST analysis. This ninth interval is significantly longer than all but the first five intervals between diversification events (which we expect to be relatively long given the small number of lineages available to speciate early in the clade's history; Fig. 3B ). Second, an anomalously long ninth interval is consistently recovered from separate analyses of each of the four genes that we used in our combined-data analysis (Fig. S2) , so the pattern is not attributable to a single locus. Finally, the pattern in question does not depend on our choice of calibration points, because a similarly long ninth interval was recovered from BEAST analyses based on relative as well as absolute time (Table 1) . Simulations suggest that, strictly speaking, a mass extinction event cannot be distinguished from a period of evolutionary stasis (i.e., no speciation or extinction; Stadler 2011b). However, we are unaware of any plausible mechanism that could explain a 5.6 Ma period of evolutionary stasis in an ecologically and geologically dynamic region such as South America in the Miocene. Thus, both diversification-parameter estimation using a composite likelihood model, and analysis of anomalous branching-time data suggest the substantial impact of extinction in didelphid evolutionary history.

didelphids (Simpson 1945; Clemens 1979; McKenna and Bell 1997) , recent phylogenetic analyses have shown that most of these extinct groups (including alphadontids, herpetotheriids, pediomyids, and stagodontids) are stem taxa and not members of the crown clade Marsupialia (Rougier et al. 1998; Wible et al. 2001; Luo et al. 2003; Sanchez-Villagra et al. 2007) . Whether marsupials originated in South America (de Muizon et al. 1997; Rougier et al. 1998) or in North America (Case et al. 2004; Horovitz et al. 2009 ) is controversial, but our reconstruction of Didelphidae as an endemic South American radiation is consistent with either scenario. Because all of the groups that have been plausibly indicated as the sister taxon of didelphids (Paucituberculata, Australidelphia, Paucituberculata + Australidelphia, or Peradectidae; Beck 2008 , Horovitz et al. 2009 ; Table S1 ) for the origin of crown-clade Didelphidae is younger than many estimates derived from previous time-calibrated phylogenies of marsupials based on nuclear gene sequences (Table 2) . Most prior studies place the MRCA of living opossums well before the Oligocene, either in the Eocene (Steiner et al. 2005; Meredith et al. 2008) or earlier (Bininda-Emonds et al. 2007) . However, Meredith et al. (2011) recently estimated crown-didelphid origination dates that lie within the 95% credibility interval surrounding our estimated date, and that also appear to be robust to different assumptions about calibration points and rates of evolution in a relaxed-clock analysis.

Our reconstruction of the early diversification history of didelphids as occurring in humid (evergreen) forests is consistent with the paleobotanical record of South America, where megathermal moist forests are known to have been present since the Paleocene (Morley 2000) , and where habitats essentially similar to modern lowland rainforests have existed since the Eocene (Burnham and Johnson 2004) . Overall, the ecotemporal pattern in our results is of an ancestrally moist-forest-adapted radiation that was just starting to invade South American dry-forest habitats by the Late Miocene, at about the time when xeric-adapted plant taxa were beginning to increase in diversity and abundance in southern South America (Ortiz-Jaureguizar and Cladera 2006; Barreda and Palazzesi 2007; Iglesias et al. 2011 ). Because our nucleargene dataset does not include all known xeric-adapted didelphid species, we cannot count the number of times that opossum lineages independently invaded dry habitats, but available specieslevel phylogenies (e.g., Giarla et al. 2010; Gutiérrez et al. 2010; Solari 2010) suggest that all omitted dry-forest species (e.g., Marmosa simonsi, M. xerophila, Monodelphis domestica) belong to monophyletic groups with basal nodes that our analyses place in the Late Miocene, so the inferred temporal context of dry-forest adaptation by didelphids is unlikely to have been biased by such omissions.

The geologically recent origin of most North American endemic opossums (e.g., Marmosa mexicana, Didelphis virginiana) implied by our reconstruction is likewise consistent with Table 2 . Estimated dates of divergence (millions of years) for comparable nodes across six analyses of marsupial diversification.

Bininda-Emmonds Meredith Meredith Meredith et al. 2005 paleontological evidence that South American mammals did not enter North America en masse prior to uplift of the Panamanian land bridge in the Pliocene (Marshall et al. 1979 (Marshall et al. , 1982 . The only biogeographic anomaly in this context is Tlacuatzin canescens, a Mexican dry-forest endemic. The sole living representative of a didelphid lineage that originated about 17 Ma in South America (Fig. 1) , the ancestor of T. canescens might have reached North America by stepping-stone dispersal over the Miocene archipelago that was emerging between the North and South American plates (Coates et al. 2004) , or it may have reached North America much later. In either case, it left behind no extant descendants in the Recent South American fauna, and it is difficult to pinpoint when the shift from mesic to xeric habitats occurred along the very long branch leading to Tlacuatzin.

Diversification studies based exclusively on Recent taxa are limited by what can be validly inferred from time-calibrated phylogenies of extant species (Nee et al. 1992 . Molecular data, in particular, are silent concerning temporal patterns of speciation and extinction for groups without living members, nor do they preserve direct indications of causality for temporal patterns reconstructed by phylogenetic analysis. Despite such inherent challenges, diversification phenomena inferred from molecular sequence data have provided important macroevolutionary perspectives on many plant and animal clades that, like didelphids, lack an adequate fossil record (e.g., Harmon et al. 2003; Kozak et al. 2006; Hines 2008; Rabosky and Lovette 2008a; Valente et al. 2010) .

The net diversification rate we estimated for didelphids (0.11 species/Ma) is comparable to background diversification rates inferred for gnathostomes (Alfaro et al. 2009) , but it is lower than that inferred for mammals across their early history (Meredith et al. 2011 ; but see Bininda-Emonds et al. 2007; Stadler 2011a) . The extinction fraction (0.77) we estimated for didelphids implies speciation and extinction rates of 0.46 and 0.36 species/Ma, respectively, values that are broadly in line with fossil estimates for origination and extinction rates averaged over continental mammal faunas (Alroy 1999; Liow et al. 2008) . Although amonglineage heterogeneity in diversification rates can cause spuriously high estimates of the extinction fraction a (Rabosky 2010), the high value inferred here is consistent with estimates from the mammal fossil record, including ∼0.8 for North American mammals since the late Cretaceous (estimated from data in Alroy 1999) and 0.75 and 0.60 for large-and small-bodied Neogene mammals of the Old World, respectively (Liow et al. 2008) . In effect, extinction appears to have played an important role in opossum evolutionary history.

Another result of our analyses that suggests an important role for extinction in the evolutionary history of didelphids is the long mid-Miocene interval of zero net lineage accumulation, an unusual and unexpected phenomenon. To be sure, changes in diversification rate are often reported in phylogenetic studies of plant and animal radiations (Erkens et al. 2007; Mcpeek and Brown 2007; Rabosky and Lovette 2008b; Alfaro et al. 2009) , but long intervals of zero net diversification flanked by episodes of rapid log-linear diversification-the "antisigmoidal" pattern of Crisp and Cook (2009) -are not. Two mechanisms have been proposed to explain such diversification plateaus. Simulation studies by and suggested that a long interval between successive speciation events in phylogenies reconstructed from Recent taxa is the predicted signature of phylogenetically overdispersed ("uniform") mass extinction, whereby one member of every pair of sister species goes extinct simultaneously. By contrast, neither clade-wide extinction (in which all members of a particular clade go extinct) nor random mass extinction (in which extinction is equiprobably distributed across a phylogeny) seemed to leave a clear trace in their simulated LTT plots. Crisp and Cook (2009) , however, described simulations in which high (≥ 90%) random mass extinctions resulted in LTT plots with a plateau flanked by steeper intervals of log-linear lineage accumulation, essentially the same pattern as that recovered from phylogenetically overdispersed mass extinction with substantially lower extinction fractions .

Although the Miocene witnessed global climatic cooling and large-scale tectonic activity (Zachos et al. 2001; Potter and Szatmari 2009) , neither Miocene climate change nor tectonism is known to have caused mass extinctions in the Neotropical biota. In fact, no evidence of Miocene mass extinction has previously been reported from any molecular-phylogenetic analysis of Neotropical organisms. Instead, steady Miocene diversificationwithout conspicuous gaps between successive speciation eventshas been reported from recent molecular-phylogenetic analyses of several species-rich and widely distributed Neotropical clades, including bactridine palms (Eiserhardt et al. 2011) , euglossine bees (Ramírez et al. 2010) , and furnariid birds (Derryberry et al. 2011) . Taken together, these observations suggest that any Miocene extinction events in the South American biota were restricted in ecological or taxonomic scope. In particular, climate change, volcanism, bolide impact events, and other environmental catastrophes that could be expected to have affected the entire regional biota seem contraindicated by such results. Of known Miocene events that might have adversely affected diversification rates in some South American clades, but not in others, two possibilities merit consideration.

Beginning sometime around 23 Ma, much of western Amazonia was inundated by the Pebas System, an enormous lacustrine complex that reached its maximum extent around 10 to 14 Ma, and persisted until approximately 8 Ma (Hoorn 1994; Wesselingh et al. 2002; Wesselingh 2006) . These wetlands must have substantially reduced the extent of rainforest habitats in tropical South America and would presumably have had deleterious effects on the continental diversity of terrestrial rainforest clades; such effects might have included phylogenetically overdispersed extinctions if the ranges of closely related species with similar niche requirements were compressed onto surrounding shields and foothills. The subsequent draining of these wetlands is hypothesized to have exposed over a million square kilometers of new habitat available for terrestrial colonization (Wesselingh and Salo 2006) , perhaps creating favorable conditions for rapid cladogenesis by surviving lineages in the Late Miocene.

An alternative explanation for didelphid mass extinction concerns the first arrival of predator taxa from North America, probably by stepping-stone dispersal over the Central American archipelago that was just emerging by volcanism and tectonic uplift in the Middle Miocene (Coates et al. 2004) . Miocene immigrant taxa that might have had catastrophic impacts on indigenous South American small mammals-but not, perhaps, on the plant, bird, or insect clades that do not show contemporaneous diversification plateaus-include pitvipers (Viperidae: Crotalinae) and placental carnivores (Procyonidae). Both of these clades first appear in the South American fossil record at high-latitude Late Miocene sites (Marshall et al. 1979; Albino and Montalvo 2006) , but they may have arrived and become established on the continent much earlier at tropical latitudes. In fact, Late Miocene South American procyonids belong to an already-endemic genus (Cyonasua), and molecular evidence suggests that pitvipers arrived in South America during the Middle Miocene (Wüster et al. 2008) .

The notion that immigrant predators can have major faunal impacts on island continents is supported by the well-documented ecological effects of human-introduced species in Australia. In particular, predation by foxes and cats is believed to be responsible for precipitous population declines, geographic range contractions, and historical extinctions of many native Australian marsupials and rodents (Dickman 1996; Smith and Quin 1996; Short 1998; Risbey et al. 2000; Short et al. 2002; Kinnear et al. 2002; Woinarski et al. 2010) . In South America, the Miocene arrival of pitvipers and placental carnivores could have had similar consequences for naive prey species, including didelphids. Pitvipers are infrared-sensitive ambush predators of endothermal vertebrates, and many Recent Neotropical species are known to eat opossums (Voss 2013) . Recent South American procyonids seldom eat didelphids, but species of Cyonasua were substantially larger and more carnivorous than living procyonids (Soibelzon 2011 ) and might well have been effective predators of Miocene opossums.

These two hypotheses (which are not mutually exclusive) make different predictions about diversification patterns that might be observed in other clades of Neotropical organisms. If Pebas System wetlands were a major cause of Amazonian extinctions-or suppressed in situ speciation (Antonelli et al. 2009 )-during the Miocene, we would expect to see contemporaneous diversification plateaus similar to that seen in didelphids emerge from phylogenetic analyses of other nonaquatic South American lowland rainforest taxa. Unfortunately, no published diversification study currently provides a compelling test of this prediction. Some lineages of furnariid birds, for example, primarily inhabit humid forests, but others are found in dry forests and savannas, so Miocene diversification in the latter habitats could mask any rainforest extinction signal in family-level analyses of furnariid diversification (Derryberry et al. 2011) ; reanalysis of these data in light of our results might prove informative. Platyrrhine primates closely resemble didelphids in modern ecogeographic distribution and were likewise restricted to tropical South America in the Miocene, but platyrrhine diversity is too sparsely sampled in published molecular phylogenies (Opazo et al. 2006; Schrago 2007; Wildman et al. 2009) to confidently reconstruct Miocene diversification patterns in this clade.

If immigrant pitvipers and placental carnivores were a major cause of Early-to Middle-Miocene didelphid extinctions, we would expect to see similar diversification plateaus in LTT plots of other endemic South American small mammals that might have been vulnerable to these predators. The most appropriate group for such a test is perhaps Octodontoidea (about 190 Recent spp.), which includes many small caviomorph rodents found in Neotropical pitviper and carnivore diets, and which diversified over much the same (Oligocene-to-Recent) interval as didelphids. Densely taxon-sampled octodontoid trees are not yet available for a compelling diversification analysis of this clade, but octodontoid research currently underway in other laboratories could provide such results in the near future.

Although there might be additional explanations for the long mid-Miocene interval of zero net diversification in didelphid phylogeny, we are unaware of any other contemporaneous events indicated by the geological record of South America that might plausibly account for this phenomenon. Indeed, explanations for net diversification plateaus are uncommon because the phenomenon itself is rare. To the best of our knowledge, signatures of mass extinction in molecular phylogenies have previously been reported only in a single study of two Gondwanan clades of legumes (Crisp and Cook, 2009) . Ours is the first report of molecular evidence for mass extinction in any animal taxon, the first to provide a relevant statistical test, and the first to consider alternative explanations.

We emphasize that our current nuclear-gene dataset provides adequate sampling only of the early radiation of the didelphid crown clade. In particular, many recently diverged taxa (descended from Pliocene and Pleistocene speciation events) in several speciose genera (notably Marmosa, Marmosops, and Monodelphis) were not included. Therefore, our data are not informative about the later Tertiary and Quaternary history of opossums, which may or may not have been affected by biogeographic events subsequent to those discussed in this report.

FIGREF0.text: Time-scaled phylogeny of didelphid marsupials based on relaxed-clock Bayesian analysis. Colored branches indicate habitat types reconstructed by maximum likelihood optimization. Boxes at branch tips show biogeographic distributions of extant taxa: shading only in the top half of the box indicates North American endemics, shading in the bottom half only indicates South American endemics, shading in both halves indicates distributions that span both continents. Circles at internal nodes indicate the probability that cladogenic event occurred within South America (gray) or involved dispersal across the Panamanian Isthmus (white). Representative didelphid genera are shown to the right of the tree, from top to bottom: Thylamys, Gracilinanus, Chironectes, Marmosa, Monodelphis, and Caluromys.

FIGREF1.text: Likelihood surface for the didelphid branching-time interval data over extinction fraction (a = μ/λ) and net diversification rate (r = λ − μ). The maximum likelihood estimate is shown as a point, and the 1, 2, and 3 log-likelihood unit contours are plotted as nested lines on this surface (the parameter area within three log-likelihood units represents an approximate 95% confidence interval).

FIGREF2.text: Patterns of diversification for didelphids. (A)The semi-log, lineage-through-time (LTT) plot based on the didelphid phylogeny shown inFigure 1. Terminal divergences were trimmed from the tree beginning at 6 Ma, the point at which we were certain all lineages had been sampled. (B) The 95% credible intervals (CIs) of branching-time intervals (the time between each lineage splitting event i and the following split i + 1) recovered from a Bayesian analysis of didelphid phylogeny and branching times (N = 10,000; see Materials and Methods). Each 95% CI is drawn opposite the corresponding splitting event i in the accompanying LTT plot. The length of the ninth branching-time interval (black) is significantly longer than all but the first five of the remaining intervals (gray); asterisks indicate intervals that are significantly shorter than the ninth interval (not corrected for multiple comparisons).
